qas.question: When was the 14th Amendment to the US Constitution created?
What was the intent of the 14th Amendment?
What clauses does the 14th Amendment include?

answers.text: due process and equal protection clauses

qas.question: What does the 14th Amendment also introduce the concept of?

answers.text: incorporation of all relevant federal rights against the states

qas.question: What has the doctrine of incorporation been used to ensure?

answers.text: application of most of the rights enumerated in the Bill of Rights to the states

qas.question: When was the 13th Amendment to the US Constitution created?
What was the intent of the 13th Amendment?
What clauses does the 13th Amendment include?

plausible_answers.text: incorporation of all relevant federal rights against the states

qas.question: What does the 13th Amendment also introduce the concept of?

plausible_answers.text: application of most of the rights enumerated in the Bill of Rights to the states

qas.question: What has the doctrine of incorporation been used to not ensure?

context: The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (Amendment XIV) is one of the <a0_0><b5_0>post-Civil War<b5_0/><a0_0/> amendments, intended to <a1_0><b6_0>secure rights for former slaves<b6_0/><a1_0/>. It includes the <a2_0>due process and equal protection clauses<a2_0/> among others. The amendment introduces the concept of <a3_0><b8_0>incorporation of all relevant federal rights against the states<b8_0/><a3_0/>. While it has not been fully implemented, the doctrine of incorporation has been used to ensure, through the <b7_0>Due Process Clause<b7_0/> and Privileges and Immunities Clause, the <a4_0><b9_0>application of most of the rights enumerated in the Bill of Rights to the states<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
